questions.question: In some of the villages they still ............................ electricity.
questions.description: We do not use the word miss to say that somebody hasn’t got something.

questions.question: She threw a glass at me, but .................................
questions.description: Lost is not used with this meaning. To miss is to fail to contact somebody.

questions.question: If we don’t hurry we will ................................ the train.
questions.description: Lost is not used with this meaning. To miss is to fail to contact somebody.

questions.question: When did you realize that the bag was ....................................?
The kitchen ought to .................................... these days.
questions.description: Somebody has to paint the kitchen. So we use a passive infinitive here.

questions.question: ................................ university students have to borrow money these days.
questions.description: We use ‘more’ before a noun without a determiner.

questions.question: You ................................ be Anna’s sister – you look just like her.
questions.description: We can use must to express the conclusion that something is certain.

questions.question: Do we need .............................. seats on the train?
questions.description: When need is used as an ordinary verb, it is followed by a to-infinitive.

questions.question: You seldom work on Saturdays, .................................?
questions.description: We use an affirmative tag after negative expressions like seldom, hardly or rarely.

questions.question: ................................... quick results when you learn a foreign language.
questions.description: We make negative imperatives with do not + infinitive.

questions.question: There is little point in asking him, ..............................?
questions.description: Clauses with little and few are followed by affirmative question tags.

questions.question: He has few reasons to quit, ...............................?
questions.description: Clauses with little and few are followed by affirmative question tags.
